Award.AwardTitle: ABI Development: Linking enzyme superfamilies to nature's repertoire of reactions
Award.AbstractNarration:
The University of California, San Francisco (San Francisco, CA) has received this ABI development award to generate new interactive tools to enhance our understanding of the relationship between the chemistry and biology of enzymes. Enzymes form the basis of nature's toolkit, performing the chemical reactions essential for life. While sophisticated computational tools and resources exist to probe the relationships between enzyme sequences and their structures (bioinformatics and computational biology), the resources to describe the chemistry of enzymes (cheminformatics) are significantly less mature. As a result, our ability to understand on a large scale how enzyme sequences and structures enable the chemistry of life is severely hampered. As sequence data continues to expand at a rate of tens of millions of sequences per year, huge numbers of new enzymes have been identified whose chemical reactions are unknown. Discovery of their chemical functions will open up new opportunities for understanding biology, ecology, and for guiding experiments that include enzyme engineering to produce new chemicals or to create enzymes capable of degrading toxic pollutants. To achieve this promise, this project will develop new tools needed to compare enzyme reactions and effectively link them to the sequence and structural features of the proteins that perform them. The results will be incorporated into a new database infrastructure, MEERCat (Mechanism and Evolution in Enzyme Reaction Catalysis), that will integrate chemical information with sequence and structural information for a large number of enzyme superfamilies.

MEERCat will use as a foundation two databases separately developed to capture these chemical and protein data, respectively. MACiE, which stands for "Mechanism, Annotation and Classification in Enzymes", is an electronic database of the chemical reaction mechanisms of enzymes. It captures chemical steps and overall reactions, along with a web-based search tool to enable users to explore these mechanisms. The Structure-Function Linkage Database (SFLD), is an electronic database that classifies enzymes into evolutionarily related sets called superfamilies and then associates specific sequence and structural features of each superfamily with the chemical capabilities of its member reaction families. It provides web-based browse, search, and analysis tools including sequence similarity networks (SSNs). SSNs enable facile mapping of chemical and other functional properties to sequences, a technology that will be used extensively in this project.

To achieve broad impact and benefit researchers worldwide, all data will be freely available for download. A user-friendly web-based interface will disseminate the results accompanied by browse, search and analysis tools. The MEERCAT infrastructure will provide online and YouTube type tutorials to train researchers in using the resource and aid others in using it for teaching. The new resource will be incorporated into current graduate coursework in bioinformatics at UCSF and in workshops held at UCSF and at other institutions to train researchers with generating and interpreting analyses performed using MEERCat tools.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Determining the molecular function of enzymes that have been inferred from genome sequencing represents a key challenge for understanding many aspects of biology. Historically, enzyme reactions have been classified using a chemistry-based system that defines numerical signatures (known as ?EC numbers? assigned by the Enzyme Nomenclature system) to describe the reactions catalyzed by biochemically characterized enzymes, irrespective of their associated sequences. Representing a separate and distinctly different approach, functional assignment of enzyme sequences of unknown function (unknowns) inferred from sequencing projects is largely done computationally, as the sheer volume of these sequences precludes biochemical characterization of even a tiny fraction of these enzymes. The first step in this latter approach involves similarity-based assignment of unknowns to evolutionarily related groups (homologous superfamilies) that contain one or more sequences of known function (knowns). Unknowns that are sufficiently similar to knowns can be annotated with those known functions. While this approach is a powerful way to computationally obtain functional predictions of unknowns on a large scale, it necessarily relies on the assumption that enzyme reaction classification tracks with sequence similarity. Evidence from many different studies establishes that this assumption is generally correct when the similarity between knowns and unknowns is high. However, as levels of similarity decrease, it can be difficult to determine the similarity cut-off at which accurate transfer of function from a known to an unknown is still justified. While this issue can be addressed experimentally on a small scale to confirm computationally inferred functional assignments, little work has been done to determine how well this assumption works on a scale that can be applied to the thousands of sets of related unknowns now available in major databases. Due to the fundamental differences in the etiologies and practice of the chemistry- and evolution-centric functional classification systems progress in this area has been hampered because we don?t know howthese systems relate to each other, especially on a large scale. 

 

This project represents an initial step toward addressing this issue by creating a new way to compare how the chemical- and evolution-based classification systems relate to each other in a way that is computationally tractable for large-scale analysis. This was achieved by integrating two published ontologies that each describes functional relationships in terms of their distinct classification systems. Through the integration of these ontologies, the concept of conserved chemical components could be linked directly to the concept of conserved sequence features, thereby allowing comparisons of each classification system on the same set of sequences. We then applied the computational infrastructure we created to support these types of comparisons by mapping the function assignments made by each classification system to protein structure- and reaction-similarity networks for a well-studied superfamily of evolutionarily related but functionally diverse enzymes. The results showed a profound and complex disconnect between the evolution- and chemistry-based systems. This conclusion mirrors previous observations suggesting that except for closely related sequences, facile annotation transfer from small numbers of characterized enzymes to the huge number of uncharacterized homologs to which they are related can be problematic. This is especially true when the degree of similarity required for accurate annotation transfer between knowns and unknowns has not been determined for large superfamilies that may contain tens of thousands of unknowns but only a tiny set of knowns whose EC numbers (or other measures of reaction similarity) may be highly diverse.

 

The work produced by this project contributes to the field of function prediction in several ways. First, it defines a new computational strategy for evaluating the extent to which it is appropriate to assume that similarity in EC number tracks with sequence similarity for the many unique enzyme superfamilies that exist in nature. Second, it introduces the value of similarity networks to illustrate and explore the differences between chemical-based and evolution-based classification of enzyme function. Third, the proof-of-concept results from this project have been published as ?A strategy for large-scale comparison of evolutionary- and reaction-based classifications of enzyme function? (PMID 32449511). This open access paper includes both a detailed description of the development of the infrastructure we created as well as a presentation of its application using as a test case a functionally diverse enzyme superfamily of nearly 50,000 sequences for which over 20 different enzyme reactions have been biochemically characterized. Accompanying this paper, interactive sequence-, reaction, and small molecule-similarity networks computed for this and two other large and functionally diverse enzyme superfamilies of interest to a broad community of researchers are freely available for download from the Structure Function Linkage Database Archive (http://sfld.rbvi.ucsf.edu).
